If the membrane potential drops below this, ions start flowing into the cell. - **Hyperpolarization**: This is when the membrane potential becomes more negative than the resting potential. So, if the resting potential is around -60 mV, hyperpolarization would mean going further into the negative range. - **Action potential**: This is a wave of depolarization (increase in positive charge) along the axon of a neuron. It causes muscle contraction and nerve impulse transmission. - **Equilibrium potential**: This occurs when the net flow of ions into and out of the cell balances, resulting in no net change in membrane potential. It's like when the concentration gradient equals the transport impedance. - **Resting potential**: This is the natural potential of the neuron's membrane under resting conditions, usually around -60 mV. - **Depolarization**: This is when the membrane potential becomes more positive than the resting potential. It's the opposite of hyperpolarization. - **Repolarization**: This is when the membrane potential decreases back towards its resting state after an action potential has caused a depolarization. - **Synapse potential**: Not sure about this one; perhaps it's not relevant here. - **Refractory period**: This is the time within which a neuron cannot fire due to electrical activity in its cell body. It's related to how neurons respond to stimuli.

- **D. equilibrium potential**: Equilibrium happens when there's no net movement of ions. This would occur during a refractory period or after a stimulus doesn't cause a significant depolarization. Our case shows both depolarization and repolarization, so it's not equilibrium.

- **J. repolarization**: This is when the membrane potential recovers from depolarization, moving towards resting potential. In our case, we go beyond rest, so it's not pure repolarization; it's also depolarization.
